_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Bulk storage tanks, pumps, pressure relief devices, cylinders

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Preparation for the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at the Ankeny IA facility began prior to the date on which
the team was assembled. The preparatory effort consisted of the review of current P&ID's and block flow
diagrams, process safety information, and identification of all components. The plants were divided into
nodes during the P&ID review.

The team was assembled and PHA training was completed prior to performing the PHA. The purpose of the
Process Hazard Analysis and the methods to be used were discussed.  Members of the PHA Team were selected on the basis of those who might offer the most experience and resources to conduct accurate analyses of the covered process. Specific job experience was considered when assembling the Team so that Management, Operations and Safety were adequately represented. The PHA was conducted the week of May 2, 2011.

OBJECTIVES
The objectives of the Process Hazard Analysis conducted for the Airgas North Central Propylene process was
to review all hazards of regulated substances, processes and procedures. The team utilized the HAZOP
technique to identify opportunities for equipment malfunction or human error that could lead to an
accidental release.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Stationary Source is Propylene. 

WORST CASE SCENARIO
A catastrophic failure of the propylene bulk tank could lead to the release of all propylene in the bulk tank.
A catastrophic failure of the bulk tank could be caused by impact of a large forklift or truck; or by the
combination of a truck pull-away and an engineering control failure. Accidental release amount would be
43,860 pounds of propylene. Bollards have been installed to block traffic from coming into contact with bulk
tank. Delivery trucks are equipped with breakaway connections.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The most likely accidental release would be caused by the failed installation of a pressure relief device or
valve on a pro

pylene cylinder. The failure could cause a very slow accidental release. The most common
propylene cylinder at this facility is what we refer to as a hundred pound cylinder. We fill this cylinder with
99 pounds of propylene.

RMP: Executive Summary [68.155] 

2.5 Has the owner or operator included a brief description of the following elements in the executive summary of the RMP: [68.155]

2.5.1 The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source? [68.155(a)]

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies for the stationary source are located in the Volume 2 Process Safety and Risk Management Manual.  Airgas' Process Safety and Risk Management Program provides instructions for implementing processes that produce employee participation, RMP related deliverables, and training activities that are compliant with 40 CFR Part 68.
2.5.2 The stationary source and regulated substances handled? [68.155(b)]
Propylene is the regulated substance that is managed at the Airgas North Central fill plant in Ankeny, IA.  Airgas North Central trucks pick up returned (empty) propylene cylinders from customer locations and transport the returned cylinders to the stationary source.  Propylene is stored at the stationary source in a large bulk tank.  Propylene is transferred from the propylene bulk tank into propylene cylinders.  The full propylene cylinders are distributed by Airgas North Central to customers.
2.5.3 The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps? [68.155(c)]

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies for the stationary source are located in the Volume 2 Process Safety and Risk Management Manual.  Airgas' Process Safety and Risk Management Program provides instructions for implementing accidental release prevention processes that are specific to propylene and that are compliant with 40 CFR Part 68.
2.5.4 The five-year accident history?

[68.155(d)]
At the time this Executive Summary was written, the covered process had not been involved with an accidental release that could have lead to property damage, catastrophic consequence, injury, or death within the past 5 years.  In addition, an accidental release had not lead to a response or restoration activity for an exposure of an environmental receptor.  Refer to Volume 2 Process Safety and Risk Management Manual Appendix Tab 222 for additional information or if applicable, updated information.

2.5.5 The emergency response program? [68.155(e)]
Employees of the stationary source will not respond to accidental releases of regulated substances.  The stationary source has an evacuation plan and has coordinated emergency response activities with local emergency responders.  Refer to Volume 2 Process Safety and Risk Management Manual Appendix Tab 2280 and Appendix Tab 3120 for additional information.
2.5.6 Planned changes to improve safety? [68.155(f)]
Implementation of the RMP processes produced 25+ changes that improved safety.  Please refer to the PSM/RMP Corrective Action/Improvement Log for additional information.  At the time the Executive Summary was written, there were no additional plans to improvement.  Future improvements will be summarized on the PSM/RMP Corrective Action/Improvement Log.
